glsa.title: oftpd DoS vulnerability
glsa.synopsis: A remotely-exploitable overflow exists in oftpd, allowing an attacker to crash the oftpd daemon.

background.p: "oftpd is designed to be as secure as an anonymous FTP server can possibly be. It runs as non-root for most of the time, and uses the Unix chroot() command to hide most of the systems directories from external users - they cannot change into them even if the server is totally compromised! It contains its own directory change code, so that it can run efficiently as a threaded server, and its own directory listing code (most FTP servers execute the system "ls" command to list files)."

description.p: Issuing a port command with a number higher than 255 causes the server to crash. The port command may be issued before any authentication takes place, meaning the attacker does not need to know a valid username and password in order to exploit this vulnerability.

impact.p: This exploit causes a denial of service.

workaround.p: While a workaround is not currently known for this issue, all users are advised to upgrade to the latest version of the affected package.
